statement.text: Femorofemoral bypass (crossover graft) is an extra-anatomic bypass that utilizes the donor iliac system to perfuse the contralateral leg in patients with unilateral iliac occlusive disease. The graft is tunneled subcutaneously across the suprapubic area, connecting the two common femoral arteries. This procedure offers excellent patency (75-85% at 5 years) with minimal physiologic stress, making it ideal for high-risk patients with isolated unilateral iliac disease.
statement.formal: Femorofemoral Bypass: Bilateral femoral exposure → Suprapubic tunnel (subcutaneous) → 6-8mm PTFE or ringed PTFE → End-to-side donor femoral → End-to-side recipient femoral | Prerequisite: Adequate donor iliac inflow | Outcome: 75-85% 5-year patency

explanation.intuition: Imagine one highway to your leg is blocked, but the other one is wide open. Femorofemoral bypass is like building a connecting road between the two sides so traffic from the good highway can reach both destinations. You're essentially stealing blood from the good side to supply the bad side - but there's usually plenty to go around.
explanation.key_insight: The success of femorofemoral bypass depends entirely on the donor iliac artery. If there's any stenosis in the donor iliac, the bypass will fail AND you might cause symptoms on the donor leg (steal phenomenon). Always evaluate the donor iliac with imaging or pressure measurements before committing to this procedure.
explanation.technical_details: Technique: (1) Patient supine, legs slightly abducted; (2) Make bilateral vertical groin incisions; (3) Expose common femoral arteries bilaterally; (4) Assess donor artery inflow (palpable pulse, Doppler, or direct pressure measurement); (5) Create subcutaneous tunnel through suprapubic area (above rectus fascia, below Scarpa's fascia); (6) Use tunneling instrument, stay superficial to avoid bladder/bowel; (7) Pass 6-8mm PTFE graft through tunnel (externally supported preferred); (8) Perform donor side anastomosis first (end-to-side); (9) Clamp graft, flush; (10) Perform recipient side anastomosis (end-to-side); (11) Release clamps, assess flow with Doppler/palpation. Graft configuration: Curving 'C' or gentle 'U' shape to prevent kinking at pubic area.
common_misconceptions: Any patent femoral pulse can serve as donor - need to assess iliac inflow quality
The graft should go straight across - a gentle curve prevents kinking at the pubis
PTFE is the only option - vein can be used if available (rarely done)
This is a temporary solution - with proper selection, long-term patency is excellent

definitions_glossary.crossover_graft: Graft connecting structures on opposite sides of the body
definitions_glossary.donor_artery: The artery providing inflow for the bypass
definitions_glossary.recipient_artery: The artery receiving flow from the bypass
definitions_glossary.steal_phenomenon: Reduction in flow to donor limb due to bypass taking blood
definitions_glossary.externally_supported_graft: PTFE with external rings to prevent compression

indications: Unilateral iliac artery occlusion with good contralateral flow
Failed iliac angioplasty/stent with good contralateral flow
High-risk patient not suitable for aortoiliac reconstruction
contraindications: Bilateral iliac occlusive disease (need aortic inflow)
Donor iliac stenosis >50% (will steal from donor leg)

technique.positioning: Supine, legs slightly abducted and externally rotated
technique.incisions: Bilateral vertical groin incisions over femoral pulse

graft_selection.alternative: Great saphenous vein (if available, rarely used)

tunnel.plane: Above rectus fascia, below Scarpa's fascia
tunnel.shape: Gentle curve (C or U) to prevent kinking

complications.prevention: Ensure adequate donor inflow, proper graft sizing
complications.management: Thrombectomy, may need iliac stent on donor side

complications.prevention: Preoperative imaging to rule out donor iliac stenosis

complications.management: Antibiotics, drainage; graft removal if deep infection

outcomes.notes: Better than axillofemoral, approaches aortobifemoral for unilateral disease

definition.@value: Extra-anatomic bypass procedure connecting the two femoral arteries across the suprapubic area for unilateral iliac occlusive disease

sources.citation: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery, 9th Edition. Extra-Anatomic Bypass.
Perler BA, et al. Femorofemoral bypass: long-term outcomes. J Vasc Surg.

learning_objectives: Describe the indications for femorofemoral bypass
Assess donor iliac artery adequacy preoperatively
Perform femorofemoral bypass with proper tunnel placement
Compare outcomes to other treatment options for iliac disease
clinical_pearls: The donor iliac MUST be evaluated - if it's bad, you'll create steal
Use externally supported graft to prevent compression at the pubis
A gentle C-curve in the tunnel prevents kinking
This is a great operation for unilateral disease with excellent outcomes
If both iliacs are diseased, you need aortic inflow (endovascular or open)

medicalCode.description: Bypass right femoral artery to left femoral artery with synthetic substitute
